sub_title: Strategic Advisor to the Department of Operations, Dutch Ministry of Defence, seconded by Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs
summary:
Joseph (Jos) Hoenen has more than 31 years of experience working in fragile states and developing countries. In 1982, he started his career as a specialist (animal husbandry/economist) in rural development programs in Yemen and Sri Lanka.  From 1987, he was the country director for a Dutch NGO (SNV) in Mali (5 yrs) and Benin (5yrs). In this period he was also asked by his HQ to restart the country program of SNV as well as Novib (Oxfam NL) and Disaster Relief Aid (now Care NL) in Rwanda in 1995 a year after the genocide. From 1996-1998, he became a consultant on strategic planning and organizational management based in and working from Guiné Bissau. Since 1999 he has worked on different positions within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. From 1999 till 2004, he was the first secretary on political governance, gender, and development for Kenya, Uganda, Somalia and South Sudan. He then worked 2 years in Eritrea as a Deputy Ambassador, after which he became seconded to the World Bank in Khartoum as a Deputy Country Manager (2006-2008).
From 2008 till August 2013, Joseph Hoenen worked as the Coordinator on Women, Peace & Security in the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs in The Hague  working with NATO, EU and other international fora. Amongst other responsibilities, he was  Co-chair of the group of signatories of the Netherlands Action Plan 1325 with 3 ministries and 41 civil organizations and knowledge institutes. 
From 1st of September 2013 till 31st of July 2018, he was seconded to the 1st German/Netherlands (NATO) Corps in Münster (Germany) working as their Civil Strategic Advisor.
And since 1st August he is seconded as the Strategic Civil Advisor to Department of Operations within the Dutch Ministry of Defence in The Hague

profile_positions.description:
1.	Responsible for mainstreaming of Women, Peace and Security  (WPS, UNSCRR 1325) within the Peace and Security Policies of the Ministry. 
2.	Networking in the field of WPS within NATO, EU, UN as well as with major international donors, like the USA government
•	Researcher/co-author of the NATO-Report "Operational Effectiveness and UN Resolution 1325– Practices and Lessons from Afghanistan" (2009). Visited for this research several times Afghanistan.  Presented the report  to Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council (EAPC-NATO) as well as the Chief of Staff c.s. of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe (SHAPE).
•	Initiated and negotiated the formulation of the  Joint Statement Clinton-Rosenthal "Supporting women's political empowerment in emerging democracies" (2011) and the "Fund for Women's empowerment in MENA region". 
3.	Trainer in Women, Peace and Security. Presentations (mostly on a yearly basis)  amonst many others for  the Netherlands Defense College Institute, Clingendael,  International Schools (Model United Nations), as well as in the Dutch/Spanish course: “Gender in Operations”, organized by the Dutch and Spanish ministries of Foreign Affairs and Defense.  
4.	Co-ordination of the process of  formulating and implementing the Dutch National Action Plan 1325. Up to now 44 organizations, 3 ministries, 4 knowledge institutes and 37 civil societies are signatories to this Plan that has a strategic focus on women’s political participation and leadership and a budget (from the Ministry) of EURO 16 million for 4 years. Focus countries are: Afghanistan, Burundi, DRC, Southern Sudan, Sudan and Colombia as well as the MENA region. Chairing and facilitating meetings and negotiation processes between signatories. 
5.	Managed (1 year) the MDG-Fund of the ministry and the start of the FLOW Fund: Funding Leadership and Opportunities for Women (FLOW). Organized the tender procedure, member of the approval committee (254 proposals assessed).
profile_positions.title: Coordinator Women, Peace & Security'

profile_positions.description:

•	supervise the work  of the Monitoring Agent and local consultants

profile_positions.description:
1.	Management of all Dutch Development Cooperation programs/activities in Eritrea. Main programs focussed on Humanitarian Aid and Rehabilitation (including Demobilisation), Public Management, Water & Environment, Education, Gender (regional & national), Governance (political & economical). 
•	As the lead donor (together with WB-representative) managed the process towards the endorsement of the Education Sector Development Program by the donor community.
•	Initiated a task force on public (finance) management & macro-economic issues. Members are WB (Asmara, Nairobi & Washington), IMF-Washington, EC-Asmara
•	Identified, assessed and processed (including negotiations) the program proposals from the Eritrea government and other organizations.
2.	Acting as Officer in Charge in the absence of the Ambassador. Besides the routine elements of political reporting, chairing internal staff meetings, the work included: 
•	chairing the EU-Heads of mission meetings
•	Chairing of EU-Trojka meetings with the Government of Eritrea
•	Undertaking diplomatic Demarches with the Government of Eritrea
•	Formulating of political & economical benchmarks to be used in political dialogue between EU and Government of Eritrea.
3.	Policy Development. 
•	Formulated/edited Multi-year Strategic Plan of the Embassy
•	Formulated/edited Year Plan 2005 and Year Plan 2006
•	Developed organisational delegation model, as well as reporting/planning tools for the staff of the Embassy.
4.	Extra. Outside of my office duties, I coach, on their request, a number of people  in different countries in Africa in their work, especially related to management, visioning, strategic thinking & planning.

profile_positions.description:
1.	Management of programs on Political Governance, Conflict Transformation and Gender in Kenya. Tasks included identification/development/formulation, appraisal, funding and monitoring of mostly multi-donor funded national (sector) programs. Responsibilities went beyond own (Netherlands funding) as in most programs I assumed Chair, Co-Chair or Vice Chair functions in joint donor funded programs.  
3.	Other responsibilities
Responsible Officer for programs in the fields of Community Development (including agriculture, micro-credit, Health, Drought, and Wetlands Management. Total budget in 2001 around € 6 million. 
4.	Policy Development in the fields mentioned above. 
5.	Advisory Work. Support to program management teams & partner organisations in developing Program Strategies, Organisational Set-Up & Management. 
6.	Management and co-ordination, positions/functions outside the Embassy. 
•	Overall Chair of the Like-Minded Donor (LiMiD) Group of 12 Embassies co-ordinating programs jointly developed and funded in the field of Governance, Legal Sector Reform and Human Rights.
•	Chair for the Donor Steering Group of the Programs:  “Donor Information Centre on Elections in Kenya”, “Support to the Electoral Commission of Kenya” and “Engendering the National Budget & PRSP Program”
•	Vice Chair of the Donor Steering Group for the Programs: “Engendering the Political Process”, “National Civic Education Program” and “Kenya Domestic Observation Program”. 
•	Co-facilitated the formulation and organisation of the “Governance, Justice, Law and Order Sector” (GJLOS) Reform Program for the Kenyan Ministries involved.
•	Vice Chair of the Jitegemee Trust, a National umbrella structure with national and regional (East African) high profile Trustees in the field of Micro-Credit for the poor in rural areas. Budget of around  € 30 million (DFID + NL).

profile_positions.description:
1.	Policy development. More than 25 policy papers, studies & publications. Themes: sustainable community development, gender, environment, decentralization, credit & savings, human resources (intercultural) management, M&E, PR, etc. 
2.	Lobbying & contract negotiation (donors, national authorities). The number of donors increased (between 1992-1996) from one to six, each with their own financial demands & procedures. Relations with the government authorities improved in such a way that they subscribed formally the Corporate Plan and promoted it as an example for their NGO-program.
3.	Program implementation, project identification & formulation, monitoring & evaluation. Formulation of 20 project documents. By end 1996, 12 projects were operational in the fields of community development, infrastructure, savings & credit, organisational strengthening. Partner organisations include farmers’ organisations, NGO’s, local authorities and ministries (at national level). 
4.	Besides the normal (financial) management monitoring tools, a specific Project M&E System (PROMES) was developed to collect and analyse quantitative and qualitative data (relational database).
5.	Regional co-ordination. I co-ordinated cross cutting issues between the different country programs of SNV in West Africa. These included the development of a corporate identity (including PR), the link with stakeholders in Europe, etc.
6.	Personnel management, etc.   Policy development & execution in the field of employment conditions and regulations, training needs, career planning, etc. By end 1996 the staff consisted of 45 academics (half Beninese and half expatriate) and more than 200 Beninese support personnel.  
7.	Financial management. Total budget in 1996 was around € 6 million coming from 6 donors.
8.     Representative on behalf of SNV, Netherlands Development Organisation (headquarters) at the Round Table on EC Decentralised Co-operation (Brussels, Belgium), including presentation of a case-study.
